column1: 17249`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/feb_2017/20170220_Damen_Wilson_47w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1501154    February 20
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By late February 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and NPL Construction Co. crews  will begin the work to install 1
column8: 752 feet of new 12-inch water main in  N. Damen Avenue
column9: from W. Argyle Street to W. Montrose Avenue and W. Wilson Avenue
column10: from N.  Damen Avenue to N. Seeley Avenue.  The old water main dates back to 1890
column11: and needs to be  replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column12: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column13: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column14: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column15: to the installation of new  pipes
column16: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column17: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column18: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column19: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column20: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column21: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column22: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column23: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  47th Ward Office: 773-868-4747  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column24: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column25: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column26: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column27: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column29: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column31: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column32: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column33: or if you would like your water  tested
column34: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column35: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column36: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column37: if you don’t already have one
column38: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column39: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely

column1: 17299`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/cfd/general/PDFs/SafetyTips/Chinese/SmokeDetector.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Smoke Detectors and Home Escape Planning Could Save Your Life    火煙探測器及家居逃生準備可救回您的性命﹗    為什麼要用火煙探測器﹖多數的火警都發生在人們熟睡時。當起火時﹐火煙探測器便 會向您提出警覺﹐及時救回您的性命。火煙探測器是由有冒煙的感覺響起警鐘。  我應購買那一類型的探測器﹖    1 光電儀是用一個光電泡發出的一束光。有煙霧進入時﹐煙霧粒子進入光室。        觸動警鐘響起。  2。電離室維持着一個小的﹐安全的幅射源使空氣分子電離稱為離子。     當有煙霧進入電離室時﹐離子便會被搖動使警鐘響起。          兩種效能是相等的﹐而兩種都需要您熟識其中的運作。您要購買一個已 經實驗室鑑定的探測器﹐例如承保實驗室(保驗)您便可知道已符合某種實 驗的要求。    我應在何處安裝探測器﹖火煙冒起是向上昇的﹐最好把探測器安放在天花或在天花下 面內牆的高處。如果探測器是在不通風的小室或一個可移動的小房下﹐則該探測器 應安放在天花內牆四至十二寸之下。  在一間多層的屋宇﹐每層都應裝置探測器。在一樓應安放在天花下的梯井。該探測 器應在睡房十五尺內裝置﹐當門關閉時﹐亦可聽到聲音。但要記着不要安裝在距離空 氣流動器三尺之內。這可把火煙吹去。亦不可把探測器裝置在空氣回流處及睡房內 。這會使火煙再流動和沖淡及使警鐘訊號延誤。  如果您裝置一個以上的探測器以上﹐您便應考慮購買全套系統以便聯系起來。這樣﹐ 當一個探測器有冒煙訊號﹐所有探測器都會使系統警鐘響起。  怎樣使用探測器﹖使用探測器有兩個方法﹕    1。電池         這是最易安裝的﹐這不需要在戶外或用電線接駁。但每年必需換兩次電池。我們提  議您在春季及秋季更改時鐘時更換。在更換時﹐所有用電池的探測器要更換時都設 備響動困擾的訊號﹐該訊號一般在七天內發出﹐這是向您告知要檢查探測器﹐換電池﹐以 延展有效使用﹐    2。家庭的電流       使用家庭電流探測器有兩種方法﹐可在任何牆上安置插座或用電路系統作永久      性的接駁入屋內電流系統。    我怎樣保用探測器﹖污染﹐溫度驟改變及烹調時抽氣機可引來誤導的訊號或探測器的 故障。為防範此類誤導訊號﹐應把探測器遠離空氣通孔﹐冷氣機及風扇。要保持定期 性的抽氣及打抹以免污染﹐不可在探測器蓋上油上漆油﹐這可使其柵欄關閉。每月檢 查探測器﹐或若有需要時更頻檢查﹐這祇需要按檢查鈕便可。

25786`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/CONTRACTS-NEGOTIATOR_1562.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code:  1562  Administrative Service  Statistical
column2: Technical and Analytical Group  Purchasing and Supply Series        CLASS TITLE:  Contracts Negotiator        CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under direction
column3: the class performs  specialized and complex contract administration work in developing and  negotiating major contracts for the procurement of professional  services and commodities; and performs related duties as required.    ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Coordinates the preparation of Request for  Qualifications (RFQ) and Request for Proposals (RFP) to solicit  competitive proposals from qualified vendors and consultants; works  with user departments in preparing detailed specifications for major  contracts and scope of services for professional service contracts;  oversees the evaluation and ranking of submitted proposals for  responsiveness to legal and contract requirements and selection  criteria; oversees the selection of the highest ranking most  responsible bidder; negotiates contract terms
column4: costs and conditions  with selected vendors or consultants; obtains required contract  documentation and monitors contracts through the approval process  troubleshooting problems that may arise; negotiates disadvantaged
column5: minority and women owned business enterprise (DBE/MBE/WBE)  requirements; reviews and approves requests for contract modifications  and amendments and re-negotiates terms and conditions as needed;  monitors contract expiration dates and processes extensions or  advertises for new contracts; keeps departments informed of the  contract process; conducts pre-construction meetings and may make site  visits to discuss specifications
column6: scope of services and other contract  requirements with contractors; keeps abreast of new commodities and  services used by the City; prepares reports of contracting activities.    RELATED DUTIES:  Maintains a list of potential vendors to ensure a  competitive bid process’; may supervise staff engaged in contract  administration or negotiation work; may assist in directing staff and  in managing a unit responsible for vendor certification and contract  compliance activities.        MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience. Graduation from an accredited college or  university with a Bachelor’s degree supplemented by four years of  progressively responsible experience in negotiating procurement  contracts
column7: or an equivalent combination of training and experience is  required.       Code:  1562  Administrative Service  Statistical
column8: Technical and Analytical Group  Purchasing and Supply Series     CLASS TITLE:  Contract Negotiator      (Cont’d)      Knowledge
column9: Abilities and Skill.  Considerable knowledge of contract  development and negotiation principles and practices.  Considerable  knowledge of the legal aspects of contracts.  Considerable knowledge  of contract specification writing.      Ability to supervise staff.  Ability to work with other City  departments in preparing contract specifications.  Ability to work  with vendors in resolving deficiencies concerning contract bids and  proposals.     Considerable contract negotiation skills.  Good skill in evaluating  contract proposals and vendor qualifications.  Good analytical skills.   Excellent oral and written communication skills.    Working Conditions.  General office environment.     Equipment.  Standard office equipment including personal computers.           NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive   as possible
column10: there may be other duties which are essential  to particular positions within the class.         July
column11: 2002  City of Chicago  Department of Personnel

column1: 8318`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2012cnstRpts/JanFeb/20120227wd_81stStBlackstone08wd.pdf`Success`Success`6`6`Not a fillable PDF.`       DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO      CUSTOMER NOTICE INFRASTRUCTURE RENEWAL PROGRAM                 February 27
column3: At Alderman Michelle A. Harris’ (8th Ward) request
column4: I am providing you with information  regarding a water construction project in your neighborhood. This is part of our approach to  renewing our city’s aging infrastructure. I see this as an opportunity to partner with you our  customers. As part of this partnership
column5: I want to be certain you are well informed about the  project. You should know where to call if you have any questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing 1
column6: 536 feet of 8-inch water main in E. 81st Street
column7: from S.  Dorchester Avenue to S. Stony Island Avenue and S. Blackstone Avenue
column8: from E. 79th Street to  E. 81st Street. The old pipe dates back to 1890
column9: and needs to be replaced.    We are coordinating with Alderman Harris’ office
column10: and she has made clear we are to put great  importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this neighborhood through the whole  term of this project. Good communication is the key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor the project  closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise and to conduct ourselves as good and  thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column11: please feel free to contact Assistant  Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1021 at any time
column12: you may leave a message.     I am also asking you to consider the enclosed information about our MeterSave Program and our  Basement Flooding Partnership (BFP).     Sincerely
column14: P.E.  Commissioner    cc:   Alderman Michelle A. Harris                8thWard    1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column15: C H I C A G O
column16: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            Do you wonder what was happening in 1890?  That’s the year the old water main was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:       CY YOUNG IN ACTION      Idaho and Wyoming became states.     The first U.S. college-level dairy school opened at the University of Wisconsin.     W.B. Purvis patented the fountain pen.      Congress created the Weather Bureau.    Rubber gloves were used in surgery for the first time.     X-rays were discovered by Wilhelm Rontgen.    Cy Young pitched and won his first major league baseball game.    The literacy rate in the United States was estimated at 13.5%.    Rose Kennedy
column19: and Dwight D. Eisenhower were born.                               81ST ST. AND BLACKSTONE AVE. WATER PROJECT         PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project:  The Department of Water Management will soon be installing 1
column20: 536 feet of 8-inch  water main in E. 81st Street
column21: from S. Dorchester Avenue to S. Stony Island Avenue and S.  Blackstone Avenue
column22: from E. 79th Street to E. 81st Street.    Reason:  The old main consists of 6-inch pipe
column23: and we want to expand capacity. Further
column24: the old  pipe dates back to 1890 and needs to be replaced.      Timing:  We will begin installing the new water main shortly
column25: and expect the work to be  completed by early June 2012. This includes restoration. Dates may change depending on  weather and other factors. If there is any appreciable change
column26: we will notify you.    Traffic: We will allow traffic to flow on 81st Street and Blackstone Avenue outside of our  working hours.  When we are working in the street
column27: we have to close it to traffic for reasons of  safety. You will always be able to reach your home or business
column28: even if it means putting a metal  plate in place.  Outside of working hours
column29: a lane will be left open for local traffic only.     Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column30: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column31: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the start  of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.     CONTACT NUMBERS   24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE                         ALDERMAN MICHELLE A. HARRIS   3-1-1   773- 874-3300   312-742-1021   ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE                                FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS               What if there is a problem?  There are always surprises in any construction project.  If you  have any concerns or questions
column32: you can ask our foreman in the street.  You can also call  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte directly at 312-742-1021.  His cell is on the voicemail  message
column33: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column34: the job is slated to conclude in early June 2012.  This includes restoration. We always hesitate to promise specific dates
column35: since we are at the mercy  of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column36: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column37: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column38: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column39: we will let you know  what is happening
column40: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column41: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column42: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.               DOES YOUR BASEMENT FLOOD?     The Department of Water Management would like to work with you and your neighbors to  reduce the risk of basement flooding.  We are promoting a collective response as the only  strategy—homeowners joining together on a neighborhood basis to work with us on  practical steps (public and private) to protect your property and peace of mind.    Want to learn more?  http://www.cityofchicago.org/watermanagement/bfp   DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO                  What is MeterSave?    MeterSave is a program to encourage Chicago homeowners to voluntarily install meters to  monitor water usage. Meters allow single family and two-flat homeowners to pay for only the  water actually used
column43: encouraging efforts to save water and money while protecting one of our  most precious natural resources.    Water charges in non-metered homes are tied to factors such as building size
column44: lot-size and  number of plumbing fixtures. Metered homes are billed according to actual use. This means that  with minimal effort
column45: participating homeowners could save money on their water bills.                Homeowner Incentives   Non-metered homeowners participating in MeterSave are eligible for the following:    A 7-year guarantee that the home water bill will be no higher than it would have if the meter   had not been installed. Bill will not exceed the assessed rate for that year.     Choice of one of the following (while supplies last):   rain barrel
column46:     water meter monitor (a refrigerator magnet that shows water usage)    outdoor water conservation kit or      And
column47: two of the above incentives if a whole block volunteers!   indoor water conservation kit   Frequently Asked Questions:   How and when do I sign up?   Interested non-metered single family and two-flat homeowners may visit www.metersave.org
column49: or call 312-744-4H2O. Please have your 12-digit account number ready.  Space is  limited based on funding availability and the number of volunteers.     What will it cost to participate?  The City of Chicago Department of Water Management will install a water meter complete with  the automatic meter reading (AMR) technology in your home FREE of charge.    AMR technology allows readings to be transmitted via wireless radio technology to Water  Management vehicles as they drive by
column50: eliminating the need for readings to take place inside the  home.  Bills will be issued bi-monthly and reflect only the actual amount of water used.     Do I have to be current on my water bill?  Yes.  Homeowners must be current on payment plan and water bill to participate in this limited  time offer of a 7-year guarantee.    For payment plan information call 312-744-4H20 (4426).      1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column51: C H I C A G O
column52: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            When can I have a meter installed?  Online meter installation scheduling is available at www.metersave.org  Otherwise
column53: Water  Management will contact you to schedule a time for meter installation.      Small changes made by Chicagoans can have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of  our water supply
column54: such as:     Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving.  This can save over 500 gallons  per month per person.    Install high-efficiency
column55: low-flow toilets.  Toilets alone consume 26% of household water  consumption.  A leaky toilet wastes 200 gallons of water per day.    Install high-efficiency washing machines. This can save energy and water consumption.    Fill the sink with dishwater instead of washing dishes with an open tap.  This saves 25  gallons per wash.    If you own a dishwasher
column56: wait until you have a full load to run it.  Dishwashers typically  use half the energy
column58: and less soap than washing dishes in the sink.    Garden with plants that are native to Chicago.  This can reduce outdoor water use by 20- 50%.    Use rain barrels to capture rainwater for watering lawns and gardens.    Use a timer or a rain sensor to monitor lawn irrigation: Sprinkler systems use thousands  of gallons of water per cycle.  Installing a timer or rain sensor will save money and water by  preventing needless watering.         WATER   Our Most Precious Resource   Lake Michigan has lost almost 32 trillion gallons of water--the equivalent of over 45 million  Olympic-sized swimming pools of water-- over the past decade. Our region could face severe  water shortages by 2050 if we fail to take decisive action.     More than half of water consumption in Chicago occurs within homes.   Over 5.4 million people-- 44% of the population of the State of Illinois
column59: depend on the Chicago  Department of Water Management to provide a reliable supply of drinking water from Lake  Michigan.     Volunteer for a meter today to save water and money!           Please go to www.metersave.org     By phone call 3-1-1

column1: 1404`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/bldgs/general/GreenPermit/GreenRoofChecklist2016.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`   Green Roof — Permit Submittal Checklist   Please provide the applicable documentation from the following list as required by the Department of Build- ings  Green  Permit  Program.  Required  forms  and  more  information  can  be  found  at  our  website  www.cityofchicago.org/buildings    General Requirements   Building Permit Application   Create  a  Building  Permit  Application  online.    Electronic  Permit  application  creation  and  document upload shall be completed by one of the following professionals:   City of Chicago-licensed Expediter
column2: Illinois-licensed Architect or Structural Engineer.  The  project  address  and  the  complete  description  of  work  stated  on  the  application  must  agree  with  the  address  and  the  scope  of  work  as  detailed  in  the  accompanying  plans.   Once the permit application number has been created
column3: please contact Sophie Marie   Martinez-Vujovic via e-mail: Sophie.Martinez@cityofchicago.org.   The following items shall be included in your permit application submittal:                           Description  of  work:  shall begin with GREEN ELEMENT PERMIT and follow with  type of installation (Green Roof installation)
column4: building occupancy type and gross  area of vegetation provided.  Contractor Information: The contact information and license numbers of the   General Contractor and all applicable subcontractors must be listed on page five  (5) of the Building Permit Application. Please provide as much of this information  as possible at initial permit application submittal.   Building Owner Information: The legal owner or the tenant responsible for the   project must sign page six (6) of the Building Permit Application.  Architect  or  Structural  Engineer  of  Record  Information:  The  Illinois  licensed  architect or structural engineer of record must sign and seal page six (6) of the  Building  Permit Application.  note: Electronic signature and seals are acceptable)   Structural Calculations   Submit Structural Calculations signed and sealed by an Illinois-licensed Architect or Struc- tural Engineer.   Green Roof Cut Sheets   Submit details provided by green roof system manufacturer.   Plans   Stamping of Plans   Upload a complete set of permit drawings signed and sealed by the Illinois-licensed  Archi- tect or Structural Engineer of Record. Drawings shall be a minimum scale of 1/8”=1’-0”   The Illinois-licensed Architect or Structural Engineer of Record and all other design profes- sionals  must  sign  and  seal  the  permit  drawing  set  cover  sheet.  All  other  drawing  sheets  shall be sealed by the design professional responsible for the preparation of the sheet se- ries.    Project Address   Include the project address on each drawing sheet Title Block.   Certification Statement   Include the following statement on the cover sheet of each permit set of drawings: “I here- by  certify  that  these  plans  were  prepared  by  me  and  to  the  best  of  my  professional  knowledge  comply  with  the  Chicago  Building  Code.”  This  statement  must  be  signed  and  sealed by the Illinois licensed Architect or Structural Engineer of Record.   Surveys   Upload a survey certified less than 60 days from the date of permit submittal   City of Chicago  Rahm Emanuel
column5: Mayor   Updated 2016-01-05      Green Roof — Permit Submittal Checklist (continued)   Code Matrix   Site Plan   Provide a completed Code Matrix on the cover sheet of the permit plan set. The Code Matrix  should be modified to include item pertinent to the current scope of work.   Provide a Site Plan drawn to scale. The Site Plan must include a north arrow
column7: street names and address of the project. Include the dimensions of all required setbacks of  the building from property lines
column8: the construction type and number of stories. The dimen- sions of the green roof trays set back from the building parapet walls shall also be included.   Building Elevations   Roof Framing Plan   Indicate all necessary dimensions to determine the height of the building and parapets.   Provide structural framing member information on submitted plans   Green Roof  Structural Details   Provide details of green roof system connection to the roof structure or ballast details.   Fee Structure   Calculate building permit using the permit fee formulas listed in the City of Chicago Permit  Fee Ordinance - Chicago Building Code Section 13-32-310.   Building Permit Fee Deposit   $300.00 permit fee deposit due at electronic submittal to begin the permit process.     Green Roof Fee Credit   A credit of $0.05 per square foot of vegetated green roof provided is applied at time of   permit issuance.                               Project Address:       I have read and understand the Green Permit Program Green Roof Submittal Checklist. I understand that the all items listed  must be complete and submitted via the E-Plan website to the Green Permit Program Project Administrator.     Applicant(s) Name(s):   (PLEASE PRINT)    Applicant Signature:        *Please contact Mrs. Sophie Marie Martinez-Vujovic with questions regarding the items above or the Green Permit Program          Process via e-mail at Sophie.Martinez@cityofchicago.org     /      /      /       Date:                                                                               City of Chicago  Rahm Emanuel

column3: and Skilled Labor  Service: Health and Welfare    Group: Inspectional   Series: Building Inspection             CLASS TITLE: BOILER INSPECTOR  CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS      Under supervision
column4: inspects and tests boiler systems to ensure boilers and water and steam pipe  connections are in compliance with applicable provisions of the municipal building code and  industry standards
column5: and performs related duties as required      ESSENTIAL DUTIES   •  Conducts inspections of high and low pressure boilers and unfired pressure vessels to ensure   that the installation and repair of boiler systems adhere to approved permit plans and  specifications   •  Checks water and steam connection pipes for leaks and defective parts and recommends   repairs in compliance with building code requirements and industry standards   •  Performs standard tests (e.g.
column8: hydrostatic) and inspects safety valve  operation
column10: and rivet tension to assess condition and operation of boiler  equipment   •  Uses testing devices including carbon monoxide detectors to measure and check the air flow of   boiler systems and assess whether the system sufficiently heats the desired space   •  Prepares inspection reports documenting findings  •   Interprets and explains provisions of the building code pertaining to the operation
column12: and repair of boiler systems to contractors
column14: and building owners  Issues citations for code violations found during inspections   •  •  Conducts follow-up inspections to ensure that repairs have been made and that code violations   have been corrected   •  Testifies at administrative hearings regarding violations identified during inspections and   corresponding citations issued   •  Prepares work reports on inspection activities  •   Inspects job sites for proper boiler system permits    NOTE:  The list of essential duties is not intended to be inclusive; there may be other duties that are   essential to particular positions within the class.        MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS   Education
column16: and Experience  •  Successful completion of a US Department of Labor registered boiler maker apprenticeship  training program and journeyman status; or an equivalent combination of education
column20: or Other Qualifications  •  A valid State of Illinois driver's license is required  •  Must have the permanent use of an automobile that is properly insured
